document.title_main: Business Requirements Document for Jaywan Mono-Badged and Co-Badged Card Issuance and Processing
document.overview: This Business Requirements Document (BRD) defines the business requirements for enabling Jaywan mono-badged and Jaywan co-badged payment cards in alignment with the Central Bank of the UAE (CBUAE) and Al Etihad Payments (AEP) mandates. The Jaywan domestic card scheme is being introduced to strengthen the UAE’s financial sovereignty, reduce payment costs, and provide a secure and seamless payment experience across domestic and selected regional and international channels. Licensed financial institutions are required to offer Jaywan mono-badged cards for domestic and GCC usage, and Jaywan co-badged cards in partnership with international payment networks (e.g. Visa, Mastercard, JCB) for domestic and international usage. This BRD covers business requirements arising from the CBUAE circular (including reference 5480/2024 as provided), AEP scheme rules as shared with the bank, and internal stakeholder workshops and discovery sessions, including those related to dual messaging, ATM/POS/SMS processes, tokenised transactions, and reconciliation and reporting expectations.
document.current_constraint: Currently, the bank issues and processes only international scheme cards (e.g. Visa, Mastercard, JCB) for domestic and international transactions. All domestic card transactions are routed via international schemes, which may result in higher interchange and processing costs, limited flexibility in applying local pricing, and dependency on cross-border scheme infrastructure. Existing systems and processes are configured primarily for international schemes and their dual messaging systems (DMS), with current documentation available for ATM, POS, SMS, and Visa DMS (including e-commerce and tokenisation transactions). Jaywan domestic scheme messages and routing rules are not yet implemented. POS tokenised transactions via domestic Jaywan rails are not fully defined. Reconciliation processes and General Ledger (GL) mapping for Jaywan scheme settlement are not yet embedded in production processes, although finance has confirmed readiness of GL details. Detailed operational procedures for reversals, refunds, chargebacks, and dispute handling under Jaywan scheme rules are partially understood and not yet fully documented. Discovery sessions for Jaywan mono-badged and co-badged additional requirements have been scheduled but are not fully completed.
document.objective: The primary business objective is to comply with the CBUAE and central government mandate requiring all licensed financial institutions to launch Jaywan co-badged cards and, where applicable, Jaywan mono-badged cards, in accordance with CBUAE circular reference 5480/2024 and related communications. Banks currently issuing Visa or Mastercard cards shall in future issue co-badged cards that support both Jaywan for domestic transactions and international schemes for cross-border usage. Card routing shall be configured such that domestic transactions are processed via the Jaywan scheme and international transactions are processed via the respective international schemes. The solution shall support secure, cost-efficient, and seamless payment experiences across ATM, POS, e-commerce, tokenised wallets (e.g. Samsung Wallet, and later Google Pay and Apple Pay), and other relevant acceptance channels. The objective includes ensuring readiness of the bank’s systems, operations, and reporting to support the Jaywan scheme locally, and to provide a foundation for future regional and international expansion in line with AEP’s roadmap, including GCC usage and bilateral arrangements (e.g. India by mid-2025 as per shared context, where applicable).
document.in_scope:
1. Enablement of Jaywan mono-badged card products for domestic UAE usage and GCC usage as per AEP guidance and CBUAE mandates, including card issuance, authorisation, clearing and settlement.
2. Enablement of Jaywan co-badged cards (Jaywan + international scheme such as Visa or Mastercard or JCB) to support domestic transactions via Jaywan rails and international transactions via the respective international scheme rails.
3. Configuration of routing logic and rules so that domestic transactions are preferentially routed to Jaywan in accordance with CBUAE and AEP directives, with support for local and GCC acceptance where applicable.
4. Alignment with documented processes for current SMS (ATM, POS), Visa DMS (e-commerce and tokenisation), and definition of to-be CBUAE/Jaywan DMS for e-commerce and tokenisation transactions.
5. Inclusion of POS tokenised transactions in scope for Jaywan scheme where applicable, including mobile wallets and token service providers as guided by AEP.
6. Definition and implementation of end-to-end processes for reversals, refunds, chargebacks, and disputes for Jaywan mono-badged and co-badged cards, consistent with AEP and international scheme rules.
7. Setup and usage of GL accounts for Jaywan-related settlement, fee income/expense and chargeback accounting, as confirmed by Finance.
8. Implementation of regulatory and scheme-mandated reporting for Jaywan transactions and performance, leveraging original reports shared by CBUAE and AEP and bank-specific MIS and reconciliation needs.
9. Discovery sessions and documentation of additional business requirements related to Jaywan mono-badged and co-badged cards, as per the scheduled meetings and agreed agendas.
10. Customer communication and awareness support from bank side, to align with AEP’s national awareness campaign and internal readiness for front-line staff.
11. Integration readiness for mobile wallet support (e.g. Samsung Wallet) for Jaywan cards, with future enablement pathways for Google Pay and Apple Pay where governed by AEP and schemes.
document.out_of_scope:
1. Detailed technical design, low-level solution design, and code-level changes, which shall be addressed in subsequent Solution Design Documents and Technical Design Documents.
2. Issuance of non-card payment instruments that are not directly part of the Jaywan domestic card scheme (e.g. instant payments, QR-only propositions), unless explicitly mandated in future CBUAE or AEP communications.
3. Definition or modification of AEP/CBUAE scheme rules themselves, including interchange and fee structures, which are governed by CBUAE and AEP and only referenced for compliance.
4. Commercial pricing strategy and product pricing for customers (fees, charges, rewards), which shall be handled as a separate product and pricing exercise by business and product teams.
5. Detailed bilateral arrangements and cross-border routing specifics with non-UAE markets (e.g. India or other countries) beyond what is mandated and documented by CBUAE/AEP at this stage; these will be covered in separate initiatives when detailed guidance is issued.
6. Replacement or re-platforming of core banking or enterprise GL systems; only configuration changes tied to Jaywan card processing and reporting are in scope.
7. Non-card-related fraud management tools beyond what is minimally required to handle Jaywan scheme fraud and monitoring requirements.
8. End-to-end design of external merchant acquiring platforms beyond the bank’s existing acquiring infrastructure; only necessary changes to support Jaywan card acceptance are in scope where the bank is an acquirer.
document.reference_documents:
1. CBUAE Circular and Central Government Mandate for Jaywan Co-Badged Cards (including reference number 5480/2024 as provided in context).
2. Al Etihad Payments (AEP) Jaywan Scheme Readiness Communications and Public Materials titled “Jaywan: UAE's new domestic card payment scheme; all your questions answered” and “Jaywan: the UAE's First Domestic Card Scheme Introduced to Strengthen the UAE's Position as a Global Hub for Digital Payments”.
3. CBUAE Classification: Public documents and circulars related to Jaywan scheme roll-out and infrastructure readiness.
4. Internal process documentation for current SMS (ATM and POS), Visa DMS for e-commerce and tokenisation transactions, and draft CBUAE DMS (to-be) documentation for e-commerce and tokenisation transactions.
5. Original reports received from CBUAE and AEP regarding Jaywan transaction reporting and reconciliation, as shared by the stakeholders.
6. Minutes of meetings and progress/queries documents (including TCS-labelled confidential internal documents) outlining discussions between Business, IT, Card Operations, GBO-ATM/CDM teams and other stakeholders on dual messaging, reversals, refunds, chargebacks, reconciliation, and GL requirements.
7. Meeting schedules and minutes of discovery sessions for additional requirements related to Jaywan mono-badged cards and Jaywan co-badged cards.

business_requirements.title_bs: Compliance with CBUAE Mandate for Jaywan Co-Badged Cards
business_requirements.description_bs: The bank shall implement Jaywan co-badged cards in accordance with the CBUAE and central government mandate, ensuring that all newly issued eligible cards are enabled for both domestic Jaywan scheme usage and international scheme usage (e.g. Visa, Mastercard, JCB) as applicable.
business_requirements.as_is_behaviour: Currently, the bank issues only international scheme-branded cards (e.g. Visa, Mastercard, JCB) that process both domestic and international transactions via international scheme rails. There is no support for Jaywan domestic scheme branding or processing, and routing is not differentiated for domestic versus international destinations based on Jaywan.
business_requirements.to_be_behaviour: The bank shall issue co-badged cards that are branded with Jaywan and at least one international card scheme (e.g. Visa, Mastercard, JCB) as per CBUAE guidance. Domestic transactions within the UAE shall be processed through the Jaywan domestic card scheme, while international transactions shall be processed via the respective international scheme rails. The card lifecycle (issuance, renewal, replacement) shall conform to CBUAE circular requirements, including future-dated mandates for mandatory migration to co-badged formats for specified customer segments.
business_requirements.pre_requisite:
1. Receipt and interpretation of final CBUAE and AEP scheme rules and implementation timelines.
2. Commercial and legal agreements between the bank, AEP, and international card schemes for co-badged arrangements.
3. Availability of updated card artwork and branding guidelines for Jaywan and co-badged variants.
4. Completion of discovery sessions between Business, IT, and external scheme stakeholders to confirm all high-level requirements.
business_requirements.acceptance_criteria:
1. The bank shall demonstrate that new primary and supplementary card issuance for in-scope products supports Jaywan co-badging in alignment with the CBUAE circular.
2. Sample test cards shall pass end-to-end domestic transaction processing via Jaywan test environment and international transaction processing via the respective international schemes.
3. CBUAE and AEP compliance checks or certification steps, where required, shall be passed without critical findings.
4. The bank shall maintain a product catalogue that clearly lists Jaywan co-badged card offerings for applicable segments, validated by Product and Compliance teams.
business_requirements.alternate_flows:
1. For card products or customer segments temporarily exempted by CBUAE or due to technical constraints (if formally documented), the bank may continue to issue international-scheme-only cards; such exceptions shall be documented and approved by Compliance.
2. In the event of Jaywan scheme unavailability (as declared by AEP), routing may temporarily fall back to international scheme processing for domestic transactions, subject to scheme and regulatory rules.

business_requirements.title_bs: Issuance and Management of Jaywan Mono-Badged Cards
business_requirements.description_bs: The bank shall design, issue, and manage Jaywan mono-badged cards intended for domestic UAE usage and GCC usage as per AEP and CBUAE guidelines, providing customers with a local scheme-only option where business strategy and regulation allow.
business_requirements.as_is_behaviour: The bank does not currently issue any domestic-only or Jaywan mono-badged cards. All cards support international usage via global schemes.
business_requirements.to_be_behaviour: The bank shall introduce Jaywan mono-badged card products which support transactions within the UAE and, where confirmed by AEP, within GCC markets. Card issuance, PIN management, mobile number capture for SMS alerts, and lifecycle events (renewals, re-issuance, closures) shall be supported in card management systems. Domestic and GCC authorisation requests for Jaywan mono-badged cards shall be routed through Jaywan rails in accordance with AEP specifications. The bank shall define eligibility criteria, usage limits, and product parameters in line with its product strategy and regulatory constraints.
business_requirements.pre_requisite:
1. Confirmation from AEP and CBUAE on permitted usage geography for mono-badged Jaywan cards (UAE-only vs. GCC-inclusive).
2. Definition of product features and target segments by Product and Business teams.
3. Card management system readiness for Jaywan-only BIN ranges and product configurations.
4. Card personalisation vendor readiness for Jaywan-only artwork and chip profile.
business_requirements.acceptance_criteria:
1. At least one Jaywan mono-badged card product shall be configured and available in production for eligible customer segments, subject to internal approvals.
2. Test cases shall show successful domestic authorisation, clearing, and settlement for Jaywan mono-badged cards via Jaywan scheme.
3. Transactions initiated outside the permitted geography (e.g. outside UAE and GCC if so restricted) shall be declined with appropriate response codes and customer messaging.
4. Card statements and online banking views shall clearly reflect Jaywan mono-badged product details for customers.
business_requirements.alternate_flows:
1. If the bank decides not to offer mono-badged Jaywan products for certain segments due to commercial reasons, the bank may focus on co-badged issuance only; such decisions shall be documented by Product and approved by Compliance.
2. For legacy mono-badged portfolios (if any exist in future), the bank may define migration strategies to co-badged cards based on revised regulations.

business_requirements.title_bs: Domestic and International Transaction Routing for Jaywan Co-Badged Cards
business_requirements.description_bs: The bank shall configure transaction routing logic such that domestic transactions for Jaywan co-badged cards are processed through the Jaywan domestic scheme while international transactions are processed through the corresponding international scheme, as mandated by CBUAE and AEP.
business_requirements.as_is_behaviour: Routing logic in the bank’s switching and card systems is currently based on international scheme BIN tables and network preferences. There is no routing differentiation for Jaywan, and domestic UAE transactions are processed via international schemes.
business_requirements.to_be_behaviour: The bank’s switching, card management, and relevant middleware systems shall support BIN-based and scheme indicator-based routing rules to ensure that transactions initiated in the UAE for Jaywan co-badged cards are routed to the Jaywan scheme. Transactions initiated outside the UAE, or as per defined geolocation or network identifiers, shall be routed to the international scheme. The routing rules shall be aligned with scheme rules, acquirer capabilities, and AEP routing specifications, and shall accommodate exception handling during outages or special scheme instructions.
business_requirements.pre_requisite:
1. Availability of Jaywan BIN ranges, network identifiers, and routing specifications from AEP.
2. Agreement with switching vendors and network providers on routing table changes and testing windows.
3. Detailed documentation from AEP and international schemes on priority rules for co-badged transactions.
4. Completion of impact analysis on existing domestic and international transaction flows.
business_requirements.acceptance_criteria:
1. Test scenarios for domestic purchases, ATM withdrawals, and e-commerce transactions shall evidence routing to Jaywan for co-badged cards used within the UAE.
2. Test scenarios for cross-border transactions shall evidence routing to the appropriate international scheme.
3. Monitoring dashboards or logs shall allow Operations to confirm which scheme processed each transaction.
4. CBUAE and AEP validation (or certification where applicable) of routing configuration shall be successfully completed.
business_requirements.alternate_flows:
1. In case of temporary Jaywan scheme downtime, the bank may switch domestic routing for co-badged cards to international schemes subject to existing scheme and regulatory guidance.
2. For merchants or channels not yet enabled for Jaywan acceptance, domestic transactions may continue to be processed via international schemes; such cases shall be tracked and phased out as acceptance grows.

business_requirements.title_bs: Support for Jaywan Transactions Across ATM, POS, E-Commerce and Tokenised Channels
business_requirements.description_bs: The bank shall enable Jaywan transactions across key channels, including ATM, POS, e-commerce, and tokenised payments (e.g. Samsung Wallet at launch, with roadmap readiness for Google Pay and Apple Pay), in accordance with AEP readiness and scheme rules.
business_requirements.as_is_behaviour: Existing ATM, POS, and e-commerce transactions are processed via international schemes. Tokenised transactions (including mobile wallets and e-commerce tokenisation) are implemented following Visa DMS and related international scheme standards. There is no support for Jaywan-specific messages or mobile wallet tokens.
business_requirements.to_be_behaviour: ATM and POS terminals, the bank switch, and host systems shall be configured to recognise Jaywan mono-badged and co-badged cards and process authorisation and financial messages using Jaywan formats and keys, in line with AEP specifications. E-commerce and tokenised transactions (including those originating from Samsung Wallet at initial phase, and later Google Pay and Apple Pay as enabled by AEP) shall be supported for Jaywan cards using the CBUAE DMS (to-be) specifications. The bank shall ensure that POS tokenised transactions, where applicable, are included in the Jaywan scope and properly routed and authorised.
business_requirements.pre_requisite:
1. Receipt of updated ATM/POS and e-commerce specifications from AEP, including CBUAE DMS requirements for Jaywan.
2. Vendor readiness for ATM/POS terminal software and e-commerce gateway changes.
3. Availability of tokenisation framework and wallet integration guidelines for Jaywan from AEP and partner schemes.
4. Agreement with Samsung Wallet (and subsequently Google Pay and Apple Pay) on timelines, certification, and test plans for Jaywan integration.
business_requirements.acceptance_criteria:
1. ATM cash withdrawal, balance enquiry and PIN services using Jaywan mono-badged and co-badged cards shall be successfully processed in test and production environments.
2. POS chip, contactless and POS tokenised transactions shall be successfully processed via Jaywan where applicable.
3. E-commerce and tokenised transactions routed via CBUAE DMS shall complete authorisation and settlement with no critical defects.
4. Integration tests with Samsung Wallet shall demonstrate successful provisioning and transaction processing for Jaywan cards, with readiness documentation for later Google Pay and Apple Pay integration.
business_requirements.alternate_flows:
1. If a specific mobile wallet does not yet support Jaywan, customers may continue to use physical card or other supported schemes until enablement is complete.
2. If certain legacy POS terminals cannot be upgraded to support Jaywan within mandated timelines, they may temporarily accept only international scheme transactions, subject to a remediation plan.

business_requirements.title_bs: Documentation and Alignment of Dual Messaging and CBUAE DMS for Jaywan
business_requirements.description_bs: The bank shall document and align its transaction processing flows to support dual messaging for Jaywan transactions, including the adoption of CBUAE DMS standards for e-commerce and tokenisation transactions, leveraging existing documentation for ATM, POS, SMS and Visa DMS.
business_requirements.as_is_behaviour: Existing documentation covers current SMS (ATM, POS) processing and Visa DMS for e-commerce and tokenised transactions. CBUAE DMS for Jaywan e-commerce and tokenisation is documented only as a to-be concept and is not implemented in production.
business_requirements.to_be_behaviour: The bank shall prepare end-to-end process flow documentation for Jaywan transactions covering SMS and DMS flows for ATM, POS, e-commerce and tokenised transactions. These flows shall specify message formats, timelines between authorisation and clearing, exception handling for mismatches, and reconciliation touchpoints. The CBUAE DMS specifications for Jaywan shall be adopted where mandated, ensuring consistent behaviour across channels and alignment with AEP documentation. Business and IT teams shall maintain up-to-date process documentation to support regulatory reviews and audits.
business_requirements.pre_requisite:
1. Receipt of finalised CBUAE DMS specifications for Jaywan from AEP/CBUAE.
2. Joint workshops between Business, IT, Card Operations and GBO-ATM/CDM teams to validate end-to-end flows.
3. Availability of original process documents and sample messages from CBUAE/AEP where applicable.
business_requirements.acceptance_criteria:
1. Approved process documents for Jaywan SMS and DMS flows shall be stored in the bank’s official repository with version control and sign-offs from Business, IT, and Compliance.
2. Test cases derived from the documented flows shall pass without critical defects during user acceptance testing.
3. Internal audit or risk reviews shall confirm that documentation adequately describes operational and control points for Jaywan transaction processing.
business_requirements.alternate_flows:
1. For channels where CBUAE DMS is not yet mandated or not technically feasible, the bank may continue to operate using existing SMS or international DMS flows with documented exceptions.
2. If CBUAE DMS requirements change, the bank shall update documentation and flows following a controlled change management process.

business_requirements.title_bs: Reversals, Refunds, Chargebacks and Disputes for Jaywan Transactions
business_requirements.description_bs: The bank shall define and implement business processes and system capabilities to support reversals, refunds, chargebacks and dispute handling for Jaywan mono-badged and co-badged card transactions in line with Jaywan and international scheme rules.
business_requirements.as_is_behaviour: Processes exist for reversals, refunds and chargebacks for international schemes (e.g. Visa, Mastercard, JCB) based on their rules. Jaywan-specific processes are not finalised. Internal meetings have highlighted the need for clarification and further updates on these flows.
business_requirements.to_be_behaviour: The bank shall implement standardised processes for handling customer and merchant disputes, including reversals, merchant-initiated refunds, issuer-initiated corrections, and chargebacks for Jaywan transactions. These processes shall distinguish between domestic Jaywan processing and international scheme processing for co-badged cards. Operational teams shall be trained on Jaywan-specific timelines, documentation requirements, and liability rules. Systems shall capture relevant data points to allow Operations to case-manage Jaywan disputes, including linkages between original transactions and subsequent financial adjustments.
business_requirements.pre_requisite:
1. Receipt of Jaywan dispute and chargeback rules from AEP.
2. Clarification sessions between Card Operations, Dispute Management, Legal and AEP as needed.
3. Availability of updated workflows within dispute management tools and case management systems.
business_requirements.acceptance_criteria:
1. Documented procedures for Jaywan reversals, refunds and chargebacks shall be approved by Card Operations and Compliance.
2. Sample dispute cases for Jaywan domestic transactions shall be successfully processed end-to-end during pilot testing.
3. MIS reports shall allow monitoring of Jaywan dispute volumes, resolutions, turnaround times and financial impact.
4. No material gaps are identified during internal quality assurance or CBUAE/AEP reviews related to Jaywan dispute handling.
business_requirements.alternate_flows:
1. For co-badged cards where the transaction is processed via an international scheme, existing international scheme dispute rules shall apply; the process shall clearly identify the applicable scheme for each case.
2. In scenarios where scheme rules are ambiguous or under revision, the bank’s Legal and Compliance teams shall define interim handling guidelines and escalate to AEP or the international scheme as required.

business_requirements.title_bs: General Ledger and Reconciliation for Jaywan Transactions
business_requirements.description_bs: The bank shall configure General Ledger (GL) accounts and reconciliation processes to support Jaywan-related postings and ensure accurate financial reporting and settlement with AEP and schemes.
business_requirements.as_is_behaviour: Finance has confirmed that GL details for Jaywan-related posting are ready based on internal planning. However, full production implementation of Jaywan GL mapping and reconciliation is not yet in place. Current reconciliation is focused on international schemes.
business_requirements.to_be_behaviour: The bank shall implement GL structures and mapping rules for Jaywan transaction types, fees, interchange, scheme charges, and settlement accounts. Reconciliation processes shall be defined for daily and periodic matching of Jaywan authorisation, clearing and settlement records against scheme files and internal GL postings. The bank shall leverage original reports shared by CBUAE and AEP and adjust internal reconciliation tools as needed. Breaks shall be identified, aged and resolved according to standard reconciliation policies.
business_requirements.pre_requisite:
1. Confirmation of final Jaywan settlement and fee structures from AEP.
2. Agreement between Finance, Operations and IT on GL account hierarchy and mapping rules for Jaywan.
3. Availability of scheme settlement and reporting file layouts from AEP.
4. Request and receipt of reconciliation documentation referred to in internal emails and meeting minutes.
business_requirements.acceptance_criteria:
1. All Jaywan-related postings shall be mapped to dedicated or clearly identified GL accounts.
2. Daily reconciliation of Jaywan settlement files against internal postings shall be completed within defined timelines, with any breaks logged and tracked.
3. Finance sign-off shall be obtained confirming that financial statements accurately represent Jaywan income, expenses and balances.
4. CBUAE or external auditor reviews shall not identify material deficiencies in Jaywan reconciliation processes.
business_requirements.alternate_flows:
1. If certain Jaywan fee components are initially aggregated into existing international scheme GLs, this shall be clearly documented and later separated when volumes justify dedicated accounts.
2. In the event of missing or delayed scheme files, provisional reconciliation rules may be applied following Finance-approved contingency procedures.

business_requirements.title_bs: Regulatory and Scheme Reporting for Jaywan
business_requirements.description_bs: The bank shall generate and submit regulatory and scheme-mandated reports related to Jaywan card transactions in accordance with CBUAE and AEP requirements, and shall enhance internal MIS for monitoring performance and compliance.
business_requirements.as_is_behaviour: Reporting is currently tailored to international schemes and existing CBUAE requirements. Jaywan-specific reporting formats and content are not yet fully implemented, although original reports from CBUAE have been shared with the business.
business_requirements.to_be_behaviour: The bank shall implement reporting solutions that produce Jaywan-related statistics such as transaction volumes, values, channel breakdowns, dispute metrics, fraud incidents, and customer adoption metrics in the formats required by CBUAE and AEP. Internal MIS shall provide dashboards and reports to senior management and operational teams to track Jaywan scheme performance, cost savings from domestic routing, and service quality indicators. The bank shall ensure timely submission of mandatory reports within stipulated due dates.
business_requirements.pre_requisite:
1. Receipt of reporting templates and submission schedules from CBUAE and AEP.
2. Availability of original example reports and file layouts provided in the context.
3. Data mapping from transaction systems to reporting data stores.
4. Agreement between Business, Risk, Compliance and IT on KPIs and MIS content.
business_requirements.acceptance_criteria:
1. All mandatory Jaywan reports as per CBUAE and AEP requirements shall be generated accurately and submitted within specified timelines.
2. Internal MIS dashboards shall be validated by Business and Risk teams for correctness and completeness.
3. Test submissions (if required) to CBUAE/AEP shall be accepted without critical data quality issues.
4. Regulatory examinations shall not identify significant lapses in Jaywan reporting.
business_requirements.alternate_flows:
1. In case of reporting system downtime, the bank may use manually compiled reports from backup data sources subject to approval and documented procedures.
2. Where certain data fields are not yet available in source systems, interim workarounds and phased enhancements shall be agreed with stakeholders.

business_requirements.title_bs: Stakeholder Discovery Sessions and Requirement Finalisation
business_requirements.description_bs: The bank shall conduct structured discovery sessions with Business, IT, and relevant stakeholders to capture and finalise additional requirements for Jaywan mono-badged and co-badged cards across all impacted areas.
business_requirements.as_is_behaviour: An initial meeting schedule exists for discovery sessions for additional requirements related to Jaywan mono-badged and co-badged cards, with agendas covering process documentation, queries to AEP, and demand discussions. Not all sessions are completed and not all requirements are baselined.
business_requirements.to_be_behaviour: The bank shall hold discovery sessions as per the agreed schedule (including meetings with attendees such as business users, BA, manager and IT representatives) to clarify process flows, Visa process applicability to Jaywan (e.g. potential adoption for JMB/JCB), routing, chargebacks, reconciliation, and reporting. Output from these sessions shall be consolidated into a baseline requirements catalogue and updated BRD versions. Queries to AEP and other external stakeholders shall be documented and tracked to closure.
business_requirements.pre_requisite:
1. Agreement on meeting calendar, participants and agendas for each discovery session.
2. Availability of existing documentation and open query logs for review during sessions.
3. Designation of a BRD owner responsible for consolidation and version control.
business_requirements.acceptance_criteria:
1. All scheduled discovery sessions as per the meeting calendar shall be completed or rescheduled with documented reasons.
2. A consolidated list of requirements and clarifications shall be documented and reviewed with key stakeholders (Business, IT, Compliance).
3. Outstanding queries to AEP and other external parties shall be logged with ownership and target closure dates.
4. The BRD shall be baselined with version approval from the designated sign-off authorities.
business_requirements.alternate_flows:
1. If certain requirements cannot be fully defined due to pending external clarifications, they shall be flagged as assumptions or dependencies and tracked via a formal log.
2. Virtual or written workshops may substitute physical meetings where scheduling constraints arise, provided outcomes are properly documented.

business_requirements.title_bs: Customer Awareness, Communication and Front-Line Readiness
business_requirements.description_bs: The bank shall ensure that customers and front-line staff are adequately informed about Jaywan mono-badged and co-badged card features, benefits, and usage, in alignment with AEP’s national awareness campaign and CBUAE expectations.
business_requirements.as_is_behaviour: AEP plans to launch an awareness campaign from April 2025 to highlight Jaywan benefits and usage, including for individuals and companies. The bank does not yet have tailored communication and training material on Jaywan for its customers and staff.
business_requirements.to_be_behaviour: The bank shall develop customer-facing materials (such as website content, FAQs, brochures and SMS/email templates) explaining Jaywan card features, domestic and international usage, security, and any changes from existing cards. Front-line staff (branches, call centre, relationship managers) shall be trained to respond to customer queries about Jaywan and to explain the implications of co-badged cards and any migration from legacy cards. Communications shall align with AEP campaign messaging and CBUAE guidelines, avoiding conflicting or misleading information.
business_requirements.pre_requisite:
1. Availability of AEP awareness campaign materials and key messages to ensure alignment.
2. Internal review and approval of communication content by Marketing, Legal and Compliance.
3. Scheduling and design of staff training sessions, including e-learning or classroom modules.
business_requirements.acceptance_criteria:
1. Customer communication material on Jaywan shall be published on official channels before or in line with Jaywan product launch dates.
2. Training completion for identified staff groups shall reach agreed thresholds, with assessments where applicable.
3. Mystery shopping or quality monitoring shall confirm that staff can adequately explain Jaywan features and address basic customer queries.
4. Customer queries and complaints related to Jaywan communication shall be monitored and show no systemic misunderstandings.
business_requirements.alternate_flows:
1. In case of delays in AEP campaign launch, the bank may proceed with its own campaign provided that core messages are approved by internal Compliance and do not contradict public information from CBUAE/AEP.
2. Staff refresher training may be scheduled after major scheme updates or product changes.

non_functional_requirements.no_of_users: The solution shall be designed to support the bank’s full active cardholder base for debit and credit cards, with capacity for growth in line with CBUAE and AEP expectations for national Jaywan adoption. Exact numbers shall be defined during sizing based on current and projected card portfolios.
non_functional_requirements.peak_volume: The solution shall be capable of handling peak authorisation volumes during high-usage periods such as salary days, public holidays, and peak shopping seasons, at least equivalent to or higher than existing international scheme transaction peaks for the bank. Specific TPS benchmarks shall be defined in technical design based on existing performance metrics.
non_functional_requirements.monthly_volume: The solution shall be engineered to process total monthly Jaywan transaction volumes expected as a proportion of the bank’s domestic card transactions, with allowance for gradual migration from international schemes to Jaywan. Detailed monthly volume estimates shall be refined using current domestic transaction statistics and adoption forecasts.
non_functional_requirements.availability: Jaywan-related systems and services (including card management, switching, and key customer channels) shall meet high availability objectives consistent with critical payment systems, typically targeting 24x7 availability with agreed maximum downtime windows aligned to regulatory and internal SLAs. Exact SLA percentages and maintenance windows shall be defined in the Service Level Agreements and operational runbooks.

impact_on_operational_process: Operational processes across Card Operations, GBO-ATM/CDM, Dispute Management, Reconciliation, and Customer Service shall be updated to incorporate Jaywan mono-badged and co-badged card activities. Card issuance, PIN management, and card replacement processes shall include Jaywan-specific steps and checks. ATM and POS monitoring teams shall track Jaywan transaction performance and handle scheme-specific incidents with AEP and acquirers. Dispute management teams shall apply Jaywan-specific rules for reversals, refunds and chargebacks, and shall coordinate with AEP and international schemes for co-badged cases. Reconciliation teams shall manage new Jaywan settlement files and GL accounts, including break identification and resolution. Front-line customer service processes, including IVR flows and contact centre scripts, shall be enhanced to cater for Jaywan-related inquiries and complaints. Change management and operational readiness reviews shall be conducted before go-live.
regulatory_impact: The initiative is driven by CBUAE and central government mandates requiring licensed financial institutions to launch Jaywan co-badged cards and ensure that cards support both domestic and international transactions as per circular reference 5480/2024 (as provided). Compliance with CBUAE circulars, AEP scheme regulations, and any subsequent clarifications is mandatory. The bank shall ensure adherence to CBUAE requirements related to domestic routing, pricing, consumer protection, dispute handling, AML/CFT monitoring, data privacy, and reporting for Jaywan transactions. The BRD and ensuing solution designs shall remain aligned with CBUAE Classification: Public documents and any confidential instructions shared via supervisory communication. Any deviations or extensions shall be subject to Compliance review, and the bank shall be prepared for supervisory examinations focused on Jaywan implementation.
reports_requirement: The bank shall implement Jaywan-related report generation that covers regulatory, scheme, and internal MIS needs. Regulatory and scheme reports shall follow CBUAE and AEP templates, including periodic statistics on transaction volumes, values, channel distribution, merchant categories, fraud and dispute metrics, and scheme performance indicators. Internal MIS shall include dashboards for management summarising adoption of Jaywan mono-badged and co-badged cards, domestic versus international routing splits, cost savings estimates, and operational KPIs (e.g. authorisation approval rates, downtime incidents). Reconciliation reports shall detail settlement positions, GL postings, and outstanding breaks for Jaywan. Original reports shared by CBUAE or AEP shall be used as baselines, and enhancements requested by Finance and Operations shall be documented and implemented where feasible.
access_requirement: Access to Jaywan-related systems and data shall follow the bank’s existing role-based access control (RBAC) model and CBUAE expectations for segregation of duties. Card Operations, Reconciliation, Dispute Management, IT Support, and Customer Service teams shall have access only to the functions and data necessary to perform their roles. Administrative access to routing rules, card product setup, and GL mappings shall be restricted to authorised personnel with appropriate approvals. Audit trails shall be maintained for all sensitive changes. Access to regulatory and scheme reports shall be limited to relevant stakeholders such as Finance, Risk, Compliance, and senior management, with proper logging of report generation and distribution.
security_requirement: The bank shall ensure that Jaywan card data and transactions are protected in accordance with CBUAE regulations, AEP scheme security requirements, and applicable payment security standards. Cardholder data shall be encrypted in transit and at rest where required, and tokenisation shall be used for mobile wallet and e-commerce use cases as per scheme guidelines. Authentication, PIN management, and CVV handling shall align with industry standards and Jaywan requirements. Fraud monitoring rules shall be updated to cover Jaywan transaction patterns, with integration to existing fraud management systems and alerting workflows. Logical and physical security controls shall be implemented for systems involved in Jaywan processing, including monitoring, logging, and incident response procedures. Any security incidents involving Jaywan shall be reported in line with regulatory incident reporting requirements.
data_requirement: The bank shall capture and store all data elements necessary to process, reconcile, and report Jaywan transactions in accordance with CBUAE, AEP, and internal governance requirements. This includes card-level data (BIN, scheme indicators for mono- and co-badged cards), transaction data (timestamps, amounts, currency, channel, merchant details, routing scheme), and lifecycle events (issuance, renewal, closure, dispute actions). Data models in card systems, switches, data warehouses, and reporting platforms shall be updated to accommodate Jaywan-specific fields and reference data. Data retention and archival shall follow regulatory and internal policies. Data quality controls shall be extended to cover Jaywan data, including validation rules, exception reporting, and remediation processes.
training_requirement: The bank shall provide targeted training for all impacted stakeholder groups prior to Jaywan go-live. Card Operations, GBO-ATM/CDM, Reconciliation, and Dispute Management teams shall receive detailed training on Jaywan processes, scheme rules, and new system functionalities. Front-line staff (branches, call centre, relationship managers) shall receive training on Jaywan card features, customer benefits, common queries, and escalation paths. IT and support teams shall be trained on operational support procedures, monitoring tools, and incident handling related to Jaywan infrastructure. Training materials shall be aligned with CBUAE and AEP communications and shall be updated as scheme rules evolve. Training completion and effectiveness shall be tracked through attendance logs, assessments, and feedback mechanisms.
